## Movements and parties, overlaps and similarities

- All sorts of constellations of movements and parties
- Some far-right [movement-parties]{style="color:darkred;"}, as discussed last week
- Several major far-right parties have movement roots, e.g. Front National [@CastelliGattinara2019]
<!-- even non-movement-parties have deep movement connections or roots: Front National (National Front, FN) has clear roots in the movement sector (e.g. Shields 2007). -->

. . . 

- More importantly, whether movement or party, many far-right actors:
    + develop [collective identities]{style="color:darkred;"}
    + [frame]{style="color:darkred;"} issues
    + [mobilise]{style="color:darkred;"} and [strategically]{style="color:darkred;"} use resources
- [these and other social movement concepts can help understand lots of far-right activity]{style="color:cadetblue;"}

# A less likely case of far-right movement influence - the Istanbul Convention {background-color="#2c844c"}

:::: {.columns}
:::{.column width="50%"}
- international treaties - usually the realm of elite politics
- Istanbul Convention [@AK-CR-Zeller2024] - combating violence against women and domestic violence
    
:::

::: {.column width="50%" .right}
<div class="tenor-gif-embed" data-postid="22182744" data-share-method="host" data-aspect-ratio="1.89349" data-width="100%"><a href="https://tenor.com/view/gender-ideology-meme-mike-myers-dr-evil-austin-powers-gif-22182744">Gender Ideology Meme GIF</a>from <a href="https://tenor.com/search/gender+ideology-gifs">Gender Ideology GIFs</a></div> <script type="text/javascript" async src="https://tenor.com/embed.js"></script>
:::
::::

- [not unique]{style="color:orange;"}: Global Compact for Migration [@rone2023StopPactForeign]

## Istanbul Convention politicisation

> Opponents criticize the Convention’s explicit [linkage between gender-based violence and structural gendered inequalities]{style="color:red;"} between women and men, the definition of gender in [Article 3(c)]{style="color:red;"} as “the socially constructed roles, behavior, activities, and attributes that a given society considers appropriate for women and men,” and [Arts. 12–16]{style="color:red;"} that require states to “promote changes in the social and cultural patterns of behavior of women and men” by means of education and other methods. The Convention [depicted as spreading “gender-ideology”]{style="color:red;"} and a threat to traditional values and gender roles ... became a target of anti-gender campaigns in Europe

## Istanbul Convention ratification status {.smaller}

Ratification of the Istanbul Convention by Council of Europe member states (EU member states in *italics*). Turkey (*) withdrew from the IC.

```{ojs}
// Create a dropdown which dataset to display (Inputs.select) - Inputs.radio for radio buttons
// FIRST VERSION: viewof dataset = Inputs.radio(["IT (FARPO)", "UnitedKingdom (FRGB)", "DE (BT)"], {label: "Dataset"})
viewof datasets = Inputs.checkbox(
  ["IT (FARPO)", "UK (FRGB)", "DE (BT)"], 
  {label: "", value: ["IT (FARPO)", "UK (FRGB)", "DE (BT)"]}
)


// Choose the corresponding dataset based on the selection
// FIRST VERSION: selected_data = dataset === "IT (FARPO)" ? Italy : dataset === "UK (FRGB)" ? UK : Germany
// Combine the selected datasets into one array
selected_data = datasets.flatMap(dataset => {
  if (dataset === "IT (FARPO)") {
    return Italy.map(d => ({...d, dataset: "Italy"}));
  } else if (dataset === "UK (FRGB)") {
    return UK.map(d => ({...d, dataset: "UK"}));
  } else if (dataset === "DE (BT)") {
    return Germany.map(d => ({...d, dataset: "Germany"}));
  }
  return [];
});
```

## Far-right demonstrations in Germany {visibility="hidden"}

::: r-stack
```{r}
#| echo: false
#| fig-width: 4
#| fig-height: 4
#| cache: true
library(tidyverse)
library(sf)
library(rnaturalearth)
library(gganimate)
library(gifski)

de_demos$Jahr <- format(as.Date(de_demos$Jahr), format = "%Y")

de_demos_grouped <- de_demos %>% 
  group_by(Ort, Jahr, lat, long) %>%
  summarise(protests = n(),
            .groups = "drop")

de_demos_grouped <- as.data.frame(de_demos_grouped)

de_demos_grouped$Latitude <- de_demos_grouped$lat
de_demos_grouped$Longitude <- de_demos_grouped$long

de_demos_grouped_sf <- de_demos_grouped %>% drop_na(lat)

de_demos_grouped_sf <- de_demos_grouped_sf %>% 
  st_as_sf(
    coords = c("long", "lat"),
    crs = st_crs("EPSG:32632") # CRS for Germany
  )

DE = ne_states(returnclass = "sf") |>
  filter(admin == "Germany") 

st_crs(de_demos_grouped_sf) <- st_crs(DE)

p <- ggplot() +
  geom_sf(data = DE, fill = "aquamarine")+
  geom_sf(data = st_boundary(DE), linewidth=0.05, color=alpha("grey30", 0.7))+
  geom_count(data = de_demos_grouped_sf,
             aes(x = Longitude, y = Latitude, size = protests, group=Jahr),
             fill="red", shape=21, alpha=0.6, color="black", stroke=0.5) +
  scale_size(name = "Number of demos", 
             breaks = c(1, 10, 25, 53),
             range = c(2, 14))+
  coord_sf(xlim = c(5, 15.5), ylim = c(47, 55)) +
  theme_void()+theme(text=element_text(size=10))+
  transition_states(Jahr, transition_length = 0, state_length = 20)+
  ggtitle('Year: {closest_state}')+ # subtitle = 'Frame {frame} of {nframes}'
  theme(plot.title = element_text(hjust = 0.5))

P = 20

animate(p, renderer = gifski_renderer(),fps = 4, nframes = 4*N+P, end_pause = P)

```

```{r}
  geom_sf(data = uk_states, fill = "lightblue")+
  geom_sf(data = st_boundary(uk_states), linewidth=0.05, color=alpha("grey30", 0.7))+
  geom_count(data = frgb_geo_grouped_sf,
             aes(x = Longitude, y = Latitude, size = protests, group=Year),
             fill="red", shape=21, alpha=0.6, color="black", stroke=0.5) +
  scale_size(name = "Number of demos", 
             breaks = c(1, 5, 15, 32),
             range = c(2, 14))+
  coord_sf(xlim = c(-8, 1.5), ylim = c(49.5, 59)) +
  theme_void()+theme(text=element_text(size=10))+
  transition_states(Year, transition_length = 0, state_length = 20)+
  ggtitle('Year: {closest_state}')+ # subtitle = 'Frame {frame} of {nframes}'
  theme(plot.title = element_text(hjust = 0.5))

P = 20

animate(m, renderer = gifski_renderer(),fps = 4, nframes = 4*N+P, end_pause = P)


```

## Issues (DE) {visibility="hidden"}

add here a text analysis

## Far-right mobilisation under left- and right-wing governments

- @Koopmans1995: data on protests 1975-1979 in France, Britain, the Netherlands, and Germany (1950-1991) -- represents 15 different governmental constellations (left, right, mixed)
    + far-right protest [increases]{style="color:darkorange;"} under left-wing governments
    + left-wing protest [increases]{style="color:darkorange;"} under right-wing governments
    + mixed governments see the [highest overall]{style="color:darkorange;"} protest levels

## Far-right mobilisation amid left- and right-wing party politics

- @hutter2014protesting: data from Western Europe
    + far-right protest [decreases]{style="color:darkorange;"} when far-right parties are well-established, strong
        * [substitution effect]{style="color:cadetblue;"}: electoral participation replaces street politics

. . . 

- @Torcal2016: 2002-2010 ESS data (much of EU space) on protest participation
    + far-right protest slightly higher under right-wing governments

## Far-right mobilisation in context

::: {.fragment .fade-in-then-semi-out}
- seems heavily influenced by conditions of *political exclusion*
:::

::: {.fragment .fade-in-then-semi-out}
- ideological posture of government matters---but not deterministic
    + movements respond not just to posture abstractly, but also to actual specific treatment
        * gov. tolerance/encouragement can increase far-right protest
        * gov. hostility/repressive action can suppress or provoke far-right protest  
        
:::

::: {.fragment .fade-in-then-semi-out}
- institutionalisation of far-right parties may reduce protest activity
:::

```{ojs}

x = [
  3.6, 1.8, 3.333, 2.283, 4.533, 2.883, 4.7, 3.6, 1.95, 4.35, 1.833, 3.917,
  4.2, 1.75, 4.7, 2.167, 1.75, 4.8, 1.6, 4.25, 1.8, 1.75, 3.45, 3.067, 4.533,
  3.6, 1.967, 4.083, 3.85, 4.433, 4.3, 4.467, 3.367, 4.033, 3.833, 2.017,
```

```{ojs}
// Compute the histogram
bins_data = {
  const histogram = d3.histogram()
    .domain(d3.extent(x))
    .thresholds(bins);
  return histogram(x);
}
```


```{ojs}
// Plot the histogram
Plot.plot({
  y: {
    grid: true
  },
  marks: [
    Plot.barY(bins_data, {
      x: d => d.x0,
      x1: d => d.x1,
      y: d => d.length,
      fill: "darkgray"
    })
  ],
  width: 600,
  height: 400
})
```
